text.p: Suppose the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] form an orthogonal but not necessarily orthonormal basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline]. What could we say about [mathjaxinline]A^ t A[/mathjaxinline]?

choice.text: It is a multiple of the identity matrix, but not necessarily the identity
It is a diagonal matrix, but not necessarily a scalar multiple of the identity matrix

font.p: The entry in the [mathjaxinline]ij[/mathjaxinline] spot of [mathjaxinline]A^ tA[/mathjaxinline] will be the dot product of the [mathjaxinline]i[/mathjaxinline]th column of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] with the [mathjaxinline]j[/mathjaxinline]th column of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. This will be zero when [mathjaxinline]i\ne j[/mathjaxinline] (i.e., when the entry is off the main diagonal) so the matrix will be diagonal. The entry in the [mathjaxinline]ii[/mathjaxinline] spot will be [mathjaxinline]\langle v_ i, v_ i\rangle = \| v_ i\| ^2[/mathjaxinline], which could be different for the various columns. So the entries along the diagonal are not necessarily the same.
